article.Heading: Budget 2017: Govt may put Rs 1,500 a month in pockets of poor, unemployed
article.Summary: In an effort to eradicate poverty, the government is working on an income transfer scheme that could form the basis of a national social security system, according to a report in The Economic Times.
article.Body:
Moneycontrol Bureau

In an effort to eradicate poverty, the government is working on an income transfer scheme that could be announced in next month’s budget, according a report in The Economic Times.

The scheme, under which 200 million poor could get Rs 1,500 a month and cost the government around Rs 3 lakh crore, could form the basis of a national social security system. However, there is a dilemma over whether it should be universal basic income or support limited to the most vulnerable.

NITI Aayog vice-chairman Arvind Panagariya had said last month that he was in favour of targeted instead of universal tranfers.

The report quoted a person familiar with the deliberations as saying the target group may include unemployed people with no source of income. A suggestion has been made to entrust the money with the woman of the household to ensure the funds are better utilised.

"There is a thinking... pros and cons of having such a scheme are being examined," a government official was quoted as saying. The official added such a programme can have broad implications in terms of delivery as well as the fiscal deficit, and any decision will have to be taken keeping these factors in mind. 

Similar schemes are in place abroad. While Finland recently announced a basic income scheme for anyone seeking employment, the UK government offers a jobseeker's allowance for the unemployed. Last week, Jammu & Kashmir became the first Indian state to commit to the idea of a universal basic income.
